awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a high pressure and temperature, biaxial deformation apparatus for earthquake and landslide studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent laboratory experiments investigating the frictional properties of rock indicate that faults are profoundly weakened at dynamic sliding rates typical of earthquakes. Understanding the cause and extent of dynamic weakening is critical to advance predictive models for nucleation, rupture propagation, and energy radiation patterns of earthquake slip events that can help mitigate the hazards of earthquakes and tsunamis.  At this time our ability to investigate dynamic weakening is severely limited because laboratory instruments capable of replicating the conditions of earthquake nucleation and rupture in the Earth do not exist. This project will design, construct, and commission an instrument that can simultaneously achieve the conditions of elevated confining pressure, pore fluid pressure and temperature, variable slip rates from µm/s to m/s, and shear displacements of at least several centimeters to systematically investigate slip instability in the Earth. The apparatus will employ a novel biaxial frame housing a pressure vessel to accommodate double-direct shear and triaxial shear configurations, and servo-hydraulic and pneumatic loading systems.  
	
The instrument will 1) advance basic research in areas relevant to mitigating natural hazards associated with earthquakes, 2) provide a state-of-the-art laboratory facility for training the next generation of researchers through an integrated graduate education and research program in geophysical rock mechanics at Texas A&M University, and 3) provide new opportunities for education and outreach to students across the STEM fields, particularly undergraduate and graduate students in engineering and geoscience. With respect to this project, the principal investigators are committed to national and international research collaboration, shared use of the new apparatus and laboratory facilities, long-term maintenance of the equipment, and sustaining a research and education program that values diversity.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

    The occurrence of an earthquake represents a frictional instability that occurs on a fault deep in the crust of the earth, at conditions of high temperature, high rock and fluid pressure, and at slip rates up to meters per second. Successful simulation of frictional slip in rock at earthquake conditions is a challenge, but is necessary to advance a physics-based understanding of earthquake slip and associated phenomena. The purpose of this project is to develop a novel instrument to directly study rock friction at conditions simulating the earthquake source. Specifically, the instrument is designed to study frictional behavior of rock from low sliding-rates (micrometers per second) to high sliding-rates (meter per second), at high loads (1 million Newtons), and that can increase the sliding rate at accelerations up to 100g and then slide at a constant rate for centimeters of slip. Over the project period we have successfully designed and built a truly unique rock deformation instrument and have used it to make new discoveries about rock friction at earthquake slip-rates.
    The instrument consists of a stiff load frame housing two vertical axis loading systems: a servo-hydraulic load system for controlled displacement at low and intermediate slip-rates (up to ten millimeters per second), and a high-speed loading system with a pneumatic actuator and a hydraulic damper that achieves displacement rates between 0.02 and 1 meter per second.  The instrument can accept a triaxial pressure vessel to test rock samples at elevated temperatures and fluid pressures, or a biaxial load frame for direct-shear testing of larger samples.  A 3-degree-of-freedom model representing the dynamics and vibrations of the machine was developed, and then modified on the basis of operational tests of a prototype, to identify and treat the source of vibrations, improve the design of the ultimate loading-system, and best emulate load paths appropriate to earthquake slip. In addition, a data acquisition system and data processing software were developed to support future research activities. The instrument is housed in the John Handin Laboratory for Experimental Rock Deformation in the Center for Tectonophysics at Texas A&M University.
    After commissioning the instrument, a series of experiments were conducted to study the dependence of friction on sliding-rate, slip history, and normal-stress. For these tests the instrument was equipped with a high-speed infrared camera used to image flash-heating on the sliding surface. The thermographic images provide the first-ever documentation of the geometry and spatial distribution of load-bearing contacts formed on rock surfaces during frictional sliding at seismic rates. The thermographs display a highly heterogeneous distribution of temperature and stress at the millimeter scale, in contrast to assumptions made in recent studies by other groups, and in contrast to published models. Our observations indicate that the reduction of friction in rock at high-speeds by flash-heating is a multi-scale phenomenon. Using our data, a more accurate multi-scale flash-weakening model has been developed that can predict the experimentally-observed, transient friction behavior.

Broader Impacts

     This project involved a new collaboration between faculty and students of the Department of Geology & Geophysics and the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Texas A&M University. It supported two students, Omid Saber working toward a Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering (awarded 2017), and Monica Barbery working toward a Ph.D. in Geology & Geophysics (to be completed in 2020). In addition, several other graduate and undergraduate students participated in research activities; some of the students are from under-represented groups in STEM education. 
    The instrument will facilitate future research on rock friction, specifically towards developing better mathematical descriptions of the frictional behavior of rock in fault zones that are necessary to advance numerical modeling of earthquake rupture, energy radiation, and ultimately physics-based, probabilistic earthquake-hazard forecasting. The instrument will be made available for researchers both within Texas A&M University (such as in Petroleum, Civil and Mechanical Engineering, and Materials Science), as well as to the external community.  In addition, as is the case with other instruments in the Handin Laboratory, the new instrument will be used for teaching and outreach activities. In particular, the instrument will be used for the laboratory component of undergraduate and graduate courses in the Department of Geology and Geophysics at Texas A&M University. This, and other instruments in our lab provide opportunities for high-impact learning and for the introduction of scientific experimentation to STEM students.
